cluster_relations.rel_desc: The underside of leaves helps protect butterfly eggs in the egg stage from predators.
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Butterfly Egg-Laying Sites and Larval Food Leaves
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: while eggs remain on the underside

remarks: Protection is indirect (via concealment/location), but treated as a protective relation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Caterpillar spines serve to protect caterpillars from their predators.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: when predators attempt to attack caterpillars
qualifiers.UncertaintyQualifier: implied target of protection is predators

remarks: Predators are implicit, inferred from nearby mention of camouflage from predators.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Caterpillar hairs provide protection against predators.
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
remarks: Target of protection (predators) inferred from context.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject provides a protective benefit to the object, reducing the object's exposure to threats or harm.
args.justification: In this relation, the underside of leaves protects the butterfly egg stage itself (the object is the beneficiary, not the threat). A predicate where the object is the protected entity (provides_protection_to) matches the modeled subject/object direction and avoids conflating the threat with the beneficiary.
args.remark: Threat (predators of butterfly eggs) is carried in qualifiers; canonical predicate focuses on subject protecting the object.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject confers protection by defending against or deterring the object, which represents a threat.
args.justification: In both relations, the subject (caterpillar spines or hairs) functions specifically to protect against predators, and the object node is the predator class (the threat), not the protected caterpillar. Using protects_against with the object as the threat yields a consistent, threat-oriented defensive predicate for these two instances.
args.remark: Protected target (caterpillars) is indicated in qualifiers; core predicate is modeled as protection against the predator threat.

args.justification: All three relations describe defensive or protective functions against predators (or predation risk), either by providing concealment for eggs or by physical defenses on caterpillars. Grouping them under an anti_predator_defense_relation captures this shared functional class across different canonical predicates.

These relations express an active functional role or agency-like effect (defensive protection) of one entity with respect to another or to a threat. This aligns better with an AGENCY-type group (functional role, defense) than with composition or pure association.
